ethnologue_comment.comment:
E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24/E25/E26 has an entry Tareng [tgr] as a separate Katuic language of Laos, noting that it must be different from Talieng
[tdf], located to the northwest, because Talieng [tdf] is Bahnaric. The Tareng [tgr] entry presumably derives from
(**hh:h:WurmHattori:Pacific**:35) where it is indeed listed as Katuic. But there is only one (geographically discontinuous)
language in Laos matching the geographic and other data in the two Tareng [tgr] and Talieng [tdf] entries
(**hh:v:L-Thongkum:13-Mon-Khmer**:104-105,
**hh:he:Schliesinger:Austro-Asiatic:Laos**:47-49) and this language is Bahnaric (**hh:v:L-Thongkum:13-Mon-Khmer**:104-105,
cf.~**hh:hv:Sidwell:Austroasiatic:2015**:185), not Katuic. Presumably the existence of two entries rather than one comes from the Katuic/Bahnaric confusion. The Stieng [stg] entry of Vietnam may also represent the same language, though there is insufficient data available to me to validate one claim or the other
(**hh:hv:Sidwell:Austroasiatic**:83,
**hh:he:Schliesinger:Austro-Asiatic:Laos**:47-49). See also: Talieng [tdf], Trieng [stg].
